text: - Hello everyone.

Welcome to our session on
building a unified agriculture
technology landscape.
My name is Hadi Nejatian,

I'm senior solutions architect
at Amazon Web Services,

telecommunication
international business units.

Today we have two
distinguished panelists with us
to discuss about this topic.
I'm gonna start with you Jayne.
- Hi Hadi. Thanks so much for having me.
My name is Jayne Landry
and I'm a Senior Vice President

of TELUS Business
Solutions and Agriculture.

- I'm Essi Ahnlund, I'm with
AWS Telecom business unit.

I lead the sales teams in
North America and in Canada.

- Thanks for having, for
having us with us. Thank you.

So I'm gonna start with
the first question.

We see lots of changes in
technology, lots of trends, lots

of new emergence of
solutions and technologies.

I would like to get your
perspective, Jayne, about

how do you see technology is
going to change the landscape
of agriculture industry?
- Yeah, that's a great question.

I would say we've already seen
technology have a dramatic
impact on the agricultural landscape.

And if I think about the,
some of the key technologies
and how they're making an impact today,
it's everything from IoT being able

to put sensors into soil to
understand where to water, when

to water, how much to water
through to agronomy solutions
to know what fertilizer, pesticides,
fungicides to put on a crop.

And this data has sort of
been all over the place.

So the ability to start
to bring it together
and turn data into insights and analytics.
So we've really seen the rise of AI
and machine learning to be able to better
match demand
and supply with agriculture so
that we are overall having less food waste

and to drive operational
efficiency across the
agricultural process.
So lots of amazing technologies

and even more coming with the
likes of robotics and drones.

So some really interesting
use cases happening there.
- Yeah, great, great feedback.

So you mentioned things
such as IoT, robotics,
artificial intelligence, so Essi,

What's your point of view on
the changes technology is going
to have on the agriculture?

- Yeah, I mean it's obvious
that technology will have a very

key role in kind of
developing the next evolution
or the next step of agriculture.
And the reason why that's important is
because the world's population is growing.
I read a statistics the other day
that gonna be 3 billion more people
by year 2050 I think it was.
That's a lot of mouths to feed
and if you think about farming

and just entry into that
business, it's becoming difficult.

So I would say technology
can help everything that
Jayne just talked about,
but also, you know, entry into farming

and provide intelligent
information as to you know, how
to enter that market.
A lot of farmers are lucky that they,

their families have
been farmers for decades
and for generations.

But what about new entrants
into, into that industry,
which is super important again

to feed the growing
population of, of the planet.

So technology comes into play
specifically for that as well.

- So yeah, because we see
the changes that it to
technology make on the food supply chain,
but are there any specific challenges
that you see on the agriculture side?
You mentioned farmers, right? Yes.

So any specific challenges
you see that are out there

that again, technology
specifically can help. Yeah.
And remove and overcome those problems?

- Yeah, I mean maybe I'll take
it kind of a step further to
what I talked about, you know, kind of

what are the creative
solutions to do farming
and to generate more food.

Things like farming on
rooftops for example,

or farming indoors where
you don't have the weather
factory, if you will.
Or how do we create farming in places

where farming didn't exist
before, like deserts for example.

You know, all of those are
kind of new entrants into,

you know, the whole
industry that will help
through technology and through a AI
and intelligent technology

and responsible technology, it
will help to, you know, kind
of entrance into that market

and it will help to be more
successful, if you will,
when it comes to farming and agriculture.

- Great point. So Jayne, you
just touched on on IoT, right?
You also mentioned data,

but are there any specific
challenges that you believe

integration of these two
can really help overcome?
- Yeah, definitely.

A lot of the agriculture
data today is in silos

because the agriculture industry
has had multiple solutions.

And so I think there's an
amazing opportunity to start
to bring this data together.
And if we can do that, we can solve some
of the key challenges

that we are seeing in the
agriculture industry today.
And one of the challenges is
that people are aging out of agriculture.

There's not a lot of
young people coming in
as Essi mentioned.
And so if we can apply technology,

we make the industry a little
bit more interesting for those
that are, are thinking about a career

and also we provide more
operational efficiency so
that we can be just much more efficient in
how we're growing our food.

I think some of the, one of
the second challenges is really
around sustainability.
Over a third of the food
that we produce today ends up in landfill.
So if we can start to understand where

that waste is happening right
throughout the value chain,

bringing together the data,
we can start to reduce

that waste and we can start
to create a circular economy
where we are making sure that instead
of going into landfill,

that food has been going
into manufacturing processes
or going for not-for-profits.
So we really start to reduce the waste.
And then the third challenge is really the
environmental challenge.

You know, we're seeing tremendous
change in climate change
and so things like water

as a resource is becoming
increasingly scarce.
And so IoT and data

and analytics can really
help us be more efficient

with our resources and
create more sustainable
agricultural practices.
- Great point. So again, as a follow up,

you just mentioned the,
those challenges then,

how do you see cloud
providers in general can make
that technology accessible?
Because one of the challenges that,
to your point was accessibility
of those technologies to farmers.

And then how do you see the,
the role of cloud providers,
you know, to make that accessible?

- Yeah, I think cloud service
providers will play a critical

role and we really appreciate
our partnership with, with AWS
as we've been exploring this space.

So everything from being able
to bring the data together,
once we can do that

and apply analytics, we can
find new sources of insight,
new sources of efficiency.
I think a second thing is really

around greener software
development processes.

A lot of these traditional
farming practices and,

and the software that supports
them have been on-prem.

So if we can move those
workloads to the cloud,

we can provide a, a
lighter footprint in terms
of, of all of that.
And then I think this third way

that cloud service providers
can really help here is
as we build out this ecosystem,

I think you can play
a key role in bringing
that ecosystem together.

If we can bring every part
of the value chain together,

we can start to look
at these opportunities
around circular economy.

- Great point. So Essi, Jayne
just mentioned about the,
the connecting that value chain,

and I think data is a great
connector of that value chain.
How do you think AWS can really facilitate

and accelerate that cloud
adoption at agriculture sector?
- Well, I'm a little bit biased

because what better company
than AWS to help you

store your data, analyze
the data, create outcome,
business outcome from that data?

But I know cloud companies
in general can, can do that.

To your point, at AWS
we also work very much

backwards from our customers
to create specific solutions.
So it's not just creating innovative
and cutting edge technology product,
but how do we create end-to-end solutions?
And to your point, it's an ecosystem.

When you look into an
industry, agriculture
or any industry, it's an ecosystem.

It's not just about the data,
it's not just about cloud,

but it's about the partners
that kind of stitch
that entire solution end-to-end.
So we have thousands of partners at AWS.
We do have a specific organization
that brings expertise specifically

for agriculture just like we
have for other industries.
So we have a team of experts
that help us develop those solutions.

We always work backwards
from our customers.
So, a lot of our services

and products are created
from feedback directly
from our customers.

So specifically for agriculture,
we actually have 18 areas

where we've developed specific
solutions for agriculture,

things like, you know, data
gathering, data analytics,

you know, predict crop
monitoring, etcetera.

So we do have that in place
and we continue to evolve

and iterate on those products
as the industry changes.

- So Jayne, it is a two
part question, right?

As a follow up to what
Essi just mentioned, right?
The way that AWS can help around providing
that data connectivity

or connectivity through data
for all of those silos there.
But what is TELUS' strategy
or TELUS' agriculture strategy about that?

Because I know TELUS has
been really at forefront
of innovating in agriculture side and,

and you've made significant
amount of investments, right?
In, in, you know, making acquisitions,
strategic acquisitions as well as lots

of in-house developments of
new technologies and solutions.
But sometimes companies have the challenge
of this data silos,

but again, in order to, to
make that data more available,
and again to be able

to enrich all those AI applications
you mentioned there's a,

there has to be a way to
provide this data connectivity
across all these data silos.
What is TELUS' agricultural strategy?

- It, TELUS, we are very proud
of our role in agriculture

and, and how we're making
investments in this space

and how we're able to
partner with our customers

to actually drive meaningful
change in this area.
So we support customers, everything from,

if you're an agriculture
provider, everything from
security access controls

as you come into the
agriculture environment,

we have agronomy solutions
that allow our farmers

to understand what
herbicides and pesticides
and fungicides they need to apply and when
and where to water.
We have animal health solutions
that use predictive analytics
to actually tailor the nutrition
and prescriptions for animal based on, on,

on their particular genomes
and, and other things.
So you can really look at increasing yield

and increasing the
increasing health of cattle.
And we have our IoT solutions.

So being able to understand
exactly what's been applied
to a field and when,

and I think the opportunity
with all of this is to again,

make farming and agriculture
more sustainable,
make it more efficient,

and ultimately just make
that whole value chain a lot,
a lot better for all of us.
- You mentioned again, IoT

because this is, this is a huge
trend happening these days,
lots of connectivity there.
So question to you Essi,

how do you think we can help
tele agriculture on side

specifically on, on on providing
all the connectivity. Yeah,
all the required services.

- I mean, I think the IoT
solutions are, you know,
a key component of the entire solution

that end-to-end solution
that I talked about.

And our demo that we have here
with TELUS is a great example

of how we kind of stitch the,
not just the IoT solutions
that we have, but also bring in partners.

So we have obviously the TELUS
agriculture platform we have

Beyond Now that provides
the marketplace for that.
We also have Red Hat in that demo
and we also have the Intraway Symphonica orchestration

because what it does is it
looks at, it looks at the land

and then it estimates based
on artificial intelligence

and also gen AI products
that we've built, it predicts

what kind of equipment, for
example, that you might need for
that specific land.
And not only that,
but it, it puts an order together for you.
So the orchestration

and placing the order is also
important so you don't have

to worry about how many
units you might need of a,
of an equipment, for example.

So it's a great example of how
yes, IoT is a key component,
but it's not the end-to-end solution.

And we use our partner
ecosystem to provide the,
the entire solution.

- Yeah. And what that does for
customers is you really then
move to more precision agronomy, right?
So that you're, rather than setting a plan
and then executing it

and just hoping something
happens, being able to do more of

that close route loop, having
monitoring in real time

and understanding what
to apply when and where.
So much more precision agronomy.

And there's some really
interesting use cases now coming

with things like drones
to, again, automate some

of these processes that
used to be manually done.
So using drones for seeding

and application of
fungicide and herbicides.
And even for harvesting,
- We can definitely have this conversation
for hours and hours.

Right. But unfortunately
we don't have enough time.
But as the wrap up

and the final question,
it's really exciting
to see two female leaders, right?

Leading in a technology and
telecommunication sector.
I wanted to get your insight and,

and actually to, to, to
just see what insight

and experience that you can
share with, with our audience,
especially young female

and women who are really
aspired to, to grow and,

and accelerate their career
growth in the telecommunication
technology sector.
So let's start with you Essi.

- Well, I, first of all,
I think we need more
women in telecom.

I think I, we can probably
say that for a lot
of other industries,
but especially in telecom, we,
we definitely need more women.

We need to close the gender
gap and how do we do that?
There are many ways, of course,

but one way to your point,
how do we get new women,

new young women into the
industry, how do we, you know,
stitch that connection,

make them interested in
coming into telecom?

And when I, when I first started
in telecom, I didn't think

telecom was any exciting
industry, if you will.

But since I spent, you
know, really a lot of, most

of my career in telecom,
it's, it's a very,
very unique industry.

It touches, I feel like it
touches every other industry

and I feel like it touches
every human being pretty much in

the world because
everybody has a cell phone,
everybody has an internet connection.
And the same for businesses.
Every business needs some sort
of a communication mechanism and network.

So it's an important in
industry from that perspective.

But the only other thing
I would say for women is
that we need to insert ourselves.
We need to educate ourselves
and we need to insert ourselves.
Because if we don't, these new products
that we're developing, talk about gen AI
or artificial intelligence.

You know, if you look at who
makes those products today,
it's probably majority men.
Not that, you know, that's a bad thing,
but I think in order to have inclusivity
and diverse perspective, we need women
to educate themselves, insert themselves,

and be at the table when
those products are created.

- And you, Jayne?
- Yeah, I mean certainly technology

and telecommunications has
traditionally been a very male
dominated industry.

So it's, but it's a fantastic
industry to work in.
And so I would really encourage more women
and to, to take a look at this industry.

If you love a fast-paced
environment, if you like, you know,

something new every day, new
business challenges to solve,
it's a great place to be.
And that's what got me hooked was the pace
of change is just increasing.
So there's always something new
to learn if you're a curious person.

And the other thing for me is
technology is not just about

the technology, it's how can
you find a business problem
with solving and apply technology to drive
to a business outcome and business value.
And I think women do an incredible job

of finding business
problems we're solving
and, you know, getting to results.
So I would really highly encourage women
to take a look at this space.
It's just such a fun place to be.

- Great. Okay ladies, once
again, thanks for joining.

So let's continue this
conversation next year.
- Thank you. Thank you for having us.
